723745f-a.title: Manhattan: Varick Street - Canal Street
723745f-a.text:
Varick Street, east side, from Canal to Grand Streets.
February 25, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

723745f-a.folder: Varick Street & Canal Street, Manhattan, NY

718038f-a.title: Manhattan: Canal Street - Varick Street
718038f-a.text:
Canal Street, west from Varick Street, showing in the
foreground, left and right respectively, the low triangular
Tunnel Adminstration Building, and the 16 story Holland Plaza
Building. The Holland funnel exit appears adjacent to the former,
utilising the southerly side of Canal Street.
January 26, 1936
W.P.A. Photo
Five Boroughs Project
CREDIT LINE IPCRATIVE
718038f-a.folder: Canal Street & Varick Street, Manhattan, NY

723736f-b.text:
71-79 Varick Street, at and adjoining the N.W. corner of Canal
Street. Demolition of the corner building and the oneestory frame
shack is in process.
February 5, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
723736f-b.folder: Varick Street & Canal Street, Manhattan, NY

718039f-a.title: Manhattan: Canal Street - Varick Street
718039f-a.text:
-anal Street (cars driving eastward thereuponJ, at Varick
Sireet (rioht center) as viewed aoutheastward to show the New
York Telephone Building across the roofa of buildings that face
on tbe south stde of Laight Street, expending from Varick Street
to West Broadway (extre.e left and ''E1'' thereupon). The amall
alley-way dividing these is St. Johns Lane. This iew at an
earlier date would be impossible as a triangular block (No. 220 ..
Bromley) was cleared in the wideninmg of Canal Street for the
Huudson Tunnel traffic. Note the signs at the right,at the mouth
of the east bound tube (Manhattan exit).
View No. 2 is similar, tho it does not show Varick Street
at hbe rioht.
April 2, 1932.
View 2: July 4, 1938.
P.L. Sperr
NO REPRODICTIONS.

718037f-b.title: Manhattan: Canal Street - Varick Street
718037f-b.text:
Canal Street, north side, west from and including Varick St.
(1)
Canal Street, S.W. corner and north side, west from and including
Varick Street. Notice the little one-story frame structure on
Varick Street, adjoining the N.W. corner. The building at the
S.W. corner will have to be demolished to make room for the
exit from the eastbound tube of the Holland Vehicular Tunnel.
December, 1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
(2)
The same, nearly five years later, just before the opening of
the Holland Vehicular Tunnel. The exit, at the left of this
picture, is closed by a temporary board fence.
October 10, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(3)
The same, a restrioted view showing the demolition of the old
houses in the block bounded by Canal, Varick, and Watts Streets.
February 5, 1929.
L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
718037f-b.folder: Canal Street & Varick Street, Manhattan, NY

723457f-b.title: Manhattan: Sullivan Street - Canal Street
723457f-b.text:
Sullivan Street, north from and including Canal Street, the year
before the demolition of buildings for the construction of the
Independent (municipal) Subway line and the southward extension of
Sixth Ave. The west side of Sullivan Street, from Canal to Grand
Streets, inclusive, including Nos. 2 to 24 Sullivan Street, will
become part of the west side of Sixth Ave. Notice the new building
(since 1922) at the S.W. corner of Grand Street. The entire east
side of Sullivan Street, from Canal to Watts Streets, including the
ten-story Powell Chocolate factory at the east corner of Canal Street,
will be razed.
Sullivan Street begins here and runs north to West 3rd Street, and,
since 1904, to Washington Square. IIt is the sixth of a group of streets
named for Revolutionary generals, and laid out west of and parallel
to Broadway.
1926.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
723457f-b.folder: Sullivan Street & Canal Street, Manhattan, NY

723737f-a.title: Manhattan: Varick Street - Canal Street

Street and opposite the western end of Grand Street.
February 12, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
